Marmota monax, commonly known as the groundhog or woodchuck, is a rodent species belonging to the Marmotinae subfamily of the Sciuridae family. It is a medium-sized mammal found in North America, primarily in the eastern and central regions of the United States and Canada.

Marmota monax is known for its distinctive physical characteristics, including a stocky, cylindrical body, short legs, and a bushy tail. Adults typically range in length from 40 to 65 centimeters and can weigh between 2.5 to 9 kilograms. Their fur is generally a grizzled grayish-brown color, which can vary in shade depending on the individual and the season.

These animals are renowned for their hibernation behavior, which is closely tied to the changing seasons. During the winter months, they enter a state of deep sleep, slowing their metabolism and body temperature to conserve energy. This hibernation period can last for several months, typically from late fall to early spring.

Marmota monax is a social animal, living in family groups and exhibiting a range of vocalizations, including high-pitched whistles and chatter. They are primarily herbivorous, feeding on a variety of grasses, plants, and crops, and play an important role in the ecosystem as burrowers and ecosystem engineers.

The groundhog's behavior and its association with the annual Groundhog Day celebration have made it a well-known and iconic species in North American culture.
